bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, March 19, 1948

div1.p: Hench informs Lyons that he will get photostats or photographs of the items that Lyons has requested for the Hall of Fame program. He suggests she contact Kean or Siler to obtain better copies of Reed's birthplace. He also suggests that she write to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and ask for their Reed photos. He is not certain he will be able to attend the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, March 19, 1948
div1.opener:
March 19, 1948
Miss Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director
Hall of Fame, New York University
1 Madison Avenue
New York 10, New York
My dear Miss Lyons:
div1.p:
I have just returned home from Florida four days ago. Since
then I have spent considerable time trying to collect the items you wish.
I have a date with our Photographic Department this Monday to go through
the files and have copies made of many of the items you want. They
should be along some time next week.

I have gone over your letter of 12 March very carefully. You
have chosen much more than you can possibly use in a program and I assume
you did this deliberately so as to give yourself the chance to pick and
choose. Five or six of the items that you request are unfortunately not
at the moment in my possession. I loaned them to the University of Vir-
ginia and I am writing today to Dr. Harry Clemons, head of the Library,
asking them to either return the material to me at once or to copy the
photographic items for you and send them to you directly (in which case
I will stop in Charlottesville May 10 or 11 and collect the material myself).
I am asking Doctor Clemons to send you photographs or photostats of the
following items:
1. Photostat of Reed's letter to Mrs. Reed, December 9, 1900.
2. Photostat of Reed's letter to Mrs. Reed, December 25 - 26, 1900.
3. Photostat of Reed's letter to Mrs. Reed, December 31 -
January 1 (The New Year's Eve Letter).
4. Photograph of the Congressional Medal. You must use this
by all means.
5. Photograph of the Walter Reed Medal of the American Society
of Tropical Medicine.
6. Photograph of Lazear's microscope.
7. Photograph of the paper cutter made from wood from Walter
Reed's birthplace and presented to Mrs. Reed. I am not
certain you will wish to use this latter, but since you
have requested it, I will ask them to photograph it.

It does not seem feasible for you to use a few of the items you
suggested. You asked for Item 14, the collective works of Finlay. I don't
know how you could use this as it is a big book. I am, however, sending you
a photograph of the first page of Finlay's original paper in Spanish and the
first page of the same paper translated by him into English, which I think
would be much more effective. You also ask for Item 15. The Senate document
No. 61. This is a book and I don't know how you would use it, but I am sending
Miss Bertha L. Lyons
- 2 -
March 19, 1948
you a photograph of the front page of Reed's original paper, the preliminary
note. You ask for Item 18, photostats of some of the clippings from Mrs.
Reed's scrapbook. I have looked them over. Unfortunately, most of the items
would not suit your purpose. Most of them are newspaper clippings about his
death and then later articles written some time after his death. Item 25,
Reed's last paper never published in full, is, I fear, too technical for your
program and seems unnecessary since you are probably going to reproduce the
first page of their much more important preliminary note. As to Item 42,
letters of Gorgas and Wood, I don't believe you would want anything I have
for this program and I do not have the letter which you specifically re-
quest. I don't know where it is. You might write General Jefferson R.
Kean, 2804 N Street, N. W., Washington, D. C. The same applies to the
letter of Doctor Welch which you quoted. Could the latter be in the Welch
Library at Hopkins?

The rest of the items you will receive as soon as possible. Most
of them from me, next week, the remaining few from the University of Virginia.
I am sending Doctor Clemons a carbon copy of this letter and if he prefers
not to photograph anything but to return my whole collection to me, I will
photograph them as soon as I can; however, at the moment, I would prefer to
have him photograph the few items for you and let me pick up all of my material
there in May. Enclosed find a carbon copy of this letter to him.

The material I send will include copies of Walter Reed's birthplace
before and after it was restored. I am not sure how well my copies will come
out. I merely have photographic postcards of the building before and after
restoration. The one before restoration is somewhat faded; however, they
may copy well. If, in the meantime, you wish to hunt for better copies, my
suggestion would be that you write first to General Kean who gave the dedica-
tion address at the memorializing of the birthplace and who should have some
good photographs; and secondly, to Colonel J. F. Siler, 1835 Eye Street,
Northwest, Washington 6, D. C., the Secretary of the Walter Reed Memorial
Association which surely would have photographs. If you do get any copies,
I would greatly appreciate having one of each (the one before and the one
after restoration) for myself as mine are not too adequate.

In addition to the things you ask for I am sending you a few extras
and I am certain that you will have more than you need. One more thing. May
I suggest that you write to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and ask
them for copies of the five photographs of Walter Reed from boyhood to man-
hood which they used in an educational film strip on the conquest of yellow
fever some years ago. Two or three of these photographs I have never seen
before and you may wish them for your program.

Had you thought of inviting Dr. L. O. Howard and his daughter, Miss
Lucy Howard. I am sure you will know who Doctor Howard is. He was the famous
entomologist who helped Reed and his associates identify their mosquitoes. At
your request, I am sending photostats of the letters between him and Reed.
Doctor Howard is very feeble and would be unable to come, nevertheless he
should be invited and it is very possible that his elderly and very charming
daughter will come. His address is 45 Pondfield Road West, Bronxville, New York.

I am somewhat disturbed about my own possible inability to attend
your affair. I got the notion that my talk before the International Congress
on Tropical Medicine was in Washington on May 18, immediately after which I
would go to New York to your affair. I am greatly disappointed to hear that
my Washington talk is to be on May 12. Since I cannot waste the whole week
east, I will have to come back and I hate to spend the money to come east
again six days later for one day, although I would certainly very much like
to attend your ceremony.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
